questions.question: What conclusion does Ralph come to about being a chief?

choices.answer: He concludes that being a chief is over-rated.
He concludes that a chief has to be able to think.
He concludes that maybe he's been too hard on them.
He concludes that Simon would have been a better chief.

questions.question: What does Ralph conclude about his own ability of being able to lead?

choices.answer: He admits that getting rescued is not so important
He admits that he's still got a lot to learn
He admits to himself that he can't think as clearly as Piggy
He is so confident that he believes he's doing a fine job

questions.question: In chapter 5, why doesn't Ralph call back the boys who have left with Jack?

choices.answer: He figures that they don't need those boys anyway.
Ralph realizes that he's been too bossy and wants to let up.
If they don't come back then he's lost them for good.
He wants to see them go off and fail miserably.

questions.question: What does Ralph say about the beast?

choices.answer: Nothing, he's got nothing to say on the subject.
He's scared out of his mind about it.
He believes they should hunt down the beast and kill it.
He wants the boys to agree that there can be no beast.

questions.question: What does Piggy say about the beast?

choices.answer: Piggy says that Jack is the beast.
There is nothing to fear unless they fear each other.
The beast is real, and the beast is hungry.
If there is a beast then they're doomed, so forget about it.

questions.question: This word means mockingly or tauntingly?

choices.answer: jeeringly
lamentably
expansively
tempestuously

questions.question: If the boys are in a perilous situation, then they are in...

choices.answer: an absurd situation
violent situation
a rejoicing situation
a dangerous situation

questions.question: How does Piggy react when Ralph says he's considering giving up leadership of the group?

choices.answer: He says, "Are you out of your mind?"
He's speechless.
He says, that he will be doomed if Jack takes over.
He likes it because he knows that he'd make a better chief.

questions.question: In chapter 6, why do the twins assume that the dead parachutist is the beast?

choices.answer: They are still half-asleep when they see the parachutist.
Because it is moving and so seems alive.
They expect to see it due to it being mentioned earlier.
all of the above

questions.question: What is Jack's reaction to the news of the beast?

choices.answer: Jack says that there is no way that there is a beast.
Jack's excited.
Jack's scared like everyone else.
Jack says that it would be wise to leave the beast alone.

questions.question: Why is Jack excited about there being a beast on the island?

choices.answer: He figures a beast might taste better than a pig.
A beast might be kosher where a pig is not.
A beast is even more a challenge to hunt than a pig.
If he can kill the beast he will then become the chief.

questions.question: What does Ralph say the new place he and Ralph have just explored would be a good place for?

choices.answer: It would make a great place for a fort.
It would make a great place to build the fire.
It would make a great place to hunt for pigs.
It would make a great place to build the shelter.

questions.question: With Jack in charge of the hunt, what does Ralph daydream about?

choices.answer: Something warm to eat
a cottage on the end of the moors
his sister
his dog

questions.question: What does Ralph do when the boys start to play, putting Robert in the part of the boar?

choices.answer: He thinks the whole thing is dumb and yells at them.
He watches passively but enjoys what he sees.
He grabs Eric's spear and jabs at Robert with it.
He doesn't really know what to think.

questions.question: What feeling does Ralph have after play stabbing Robert with Eric's spear?

choices.answer: He feels bad for almost hurting Robert.
He realizes that he'd make a pretty good hunter.
He feels an overwhelming desire to stab and hurt Robert.
He wants to try it on Jack.

questions.question: Why does Robert insist they need a real pig, rather than someone to pretend to be a pig?

choices.answer: He feels the victim must be killed.
He's tired of getting hit with a spear.
He doesn't think Ralph will act so tough if it's a real pig.
For no real reason. He's just bored.

questions.question: What does Ralph sense about Jack after Ralph asks him about the pig-run?

choices.answer: That Jack is a big phony.
Ralph senses Jack's antagonism.
That Jack is really a lousy hunter.
That Jack is really afraid and wants to go home.

questions.question: How does Jack challenge Ralph?

choices.answer: He challenges Ralph to come with him to look for the beast.
He challenges Ralph to a pig hunting contest.
He challenges Ralph to a fist fight on the beach.
He challenges Ralph to call for new elections for chief.

questions.question: When Jack returns to Ralph and Roger, what does he tell them?

choices.answer: He tells them there is nothing there.
He tells them that he's found a way off the island.
That he's found a map that will lead to a treasure.
He's seen a thing that bulges and heard a plopping noise.

questions.question: Describe what the boys see and their reaction to it.

choices.answer: They see a great ape. They flee from the mountaintop
They see a dead parachutist and run from him
They see a huge pig and try to kill it
They don't see anything, but tell everybody they saw a beast
